quotes.topic_title: Radical accountability and early growth mindset
quotes.text: We really had an aggressive mentality, an aggressive approach, and what that looked like was at the time, a very small percentage of, I think HubSpot's subscription revenue would be described as self-service, so we approached the team who owned it and we were like, "Are you all working on this?" They were like, "Nah, we're working on a bunch of other stuff." We were like, "Can we take this?" They were like, "Sure, if you want it."
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of proactively taking ownership of an under-served revenue stream by asking for it rather than waiting for a mandate.

quotes.topic_title: Radical accountability and early growth mindset
quotes.text: And so, we took it and immediately blew it up, and so that attitude of saying that every problem is our problem and radical accountability and ownership mentality helped us find opportunities that maybe the business wasn't explicitly asking us to solve, but we were able to triangulate why it might be important for the business for us to solve it.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A practitioner mental model: treat every problem as yours, then justify work by triangulating business importance even without explicit asks.

quotes.topic_title: Radical accountability and early growth mindset
quotes.text: When you do that, we look hungry, so let's keep feeding us, right?
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth-team strategy: visible ownership and initiative earns more scope and resources over time.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Chris started as an ICPM at HubSpot where he helped create their early growth team and as you'll hear, shifted HubSpot towards one of the most successful product-led growth businesses in history.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete example of building an early growth team that helped drive a major shift to product-led growth at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our wide-ranging conversation, we cover what it takes to become a successful product leader in tech, what skills the most successful PMs need to build, how to find mentors, why you need to scrape your knees as an early PM.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews actionable career-development themes, including a counterintuitive emphasis on learning through early mistakes (“scrape your knees”).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, a lot of great stories and insights about what HubSpot figured out about growth across content, sales product, market segments, and growth loops.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals a multi-channel growth framework spanning content, sales-led motions, segmentation, and growth loops practitioners can study and apply.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career and something that worked really well for me a few years ago is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a practical career-acceleration tactic: forming a “personal board of directors” for ongoing feedback and decision support.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Everyone has their own zone of genius, so together we're better prepared to navigate professional pitfalls, leading to more responsibility, faster promotions, and bigger impact.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why peer groups work: combining complementary strengths to avoid pitfalls and accelerate growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that challenges the assumption that building a trusted network must take many years.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete adoption and impact data point that quantifies automation leverage in compliance work.

quotes.topic_title: VP of Product for Growth and AI
quotes.text: I've been leading PLG at HubSpot for several years now, and I recently took on the AI leadership role.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner path where growth (PLG) leadership naturally expands into AI leadership as companies operationalize AI.

quotes.topic_title: VP of Product for Growth and AI
quotes.text: It's a special place to be in and that I get to help lead HubSpot in terms of how we should be thinking about building the foundational technology to create AI-powered experiences and then also lead the strategy of how we leverage those experiences to help that B2B business builder be way more successful using our platform than they might've been in years past.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Offers a clear two-part operating model for AI in product: build foundational AI tech, then translate it into leveraged customer experiences tied to outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: VP of Product for Growth and AI
quotes.text: So, it's a really cool intersection point between those two things. There's a lot we can do there.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Emphasizes the strategic leverage at the intersection of growth and AI, implying product leaders can drive outsized impact by owning both.

quotes.topic_title: How Chris earned broader leadership scope
quotes.text: I was actually less of a feature PM and I was sort of more of a growth PM in my DNA, and so I sort of looked at this through a completely different lens and I guess I understood that what we were trying to actually do was product-led growth, but we didn't really have the shared vocabulary to call it that.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mental model shift (feature PM → growth PM) and the importance of naming/aligning on a shared strategy vocabulary (product-led growth).

quotes.topic_title: How Chris earned broader leadership scope
quotes.text: And so I think to answer your question, I think I was just willing to take some risks and really push for the things that I believed made sense even though maybe based on the titles that I had at the time, I wasn't sort of inherently given a seat at the table and really pushed my away into some of these conversations and then was eventually invited to them.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Actionable career advice: proactively enter higher-level strategic conversations before you’re formally “allowed,” and earn the invitation through contribution.

quotes.topic_title: How Chris earned broader leadership scope
quotes.text: just always had an interest in driving a strategy that was a click or two higher than maybe what my immediate team was focused on and was always curious about how other parts of the business functioned.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Encourages practitioners to widen scope by consistently operating slightly above their immediate remit and building cross-functional understanding.

quotes.topic_title: How Chris earned broader leadership scope
quotes.text: I used to spend a lot of time sitting on the sales floor, just going into the other buildings and talking to other folks, working on different parts of the business, and that's part of maybe the serendipity that I miss about being in person, which is that you might just discover something from having a casual conversation with someone at the water cooler.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable tactic for building business context and uncovering opportunities: embed with adjacent teams and seek informal conversations.

quotes.topic_title: How Chris earned broader leadership scope
quotes.text: So you absorb a bunch of context around how pieces of the business are connected and you can start to really widen your aperture in terms of the size of opportunities that might be in front of you that maybe you would've missed if you would've been so heads down on execution work.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Counterbalances execution focus with a scalable approach to impact: invest in context-building to spot larger, cross-cutting opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks: the Guinness pricing pitch
quotes.text: And we were trying to just figure out how to simplify, simplify, simplify.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A clear product/GTМ heuristic: when pricing and packaging get complex, prioritize simplification as a guiding principle.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks: the Guinness pricing pitch
quotes.text: And so, we ended up kind of pitching in the midst of pints being sort of handed every which way you could turn this vision for a completely different way we might approach pricing and packaging, and he was pretty intrigued and he said, "Why don't you come to the next executive meeting and pitch us on it?"
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of taking calculated social/professional risks to create unexpected access and influence.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks: the Guinness pricing pitch
quotes.text: I think a lot of elements of what we pitched have made their way over time into HubSpot's pricing and packaging, but it certainly I think opened the door for us and for me, speaking for myself, certainly for me to be welcomed back into that room in the future and to be able to contribute ideas towards important decisions.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Shows how even “non-adopted” proposals can compound into long-term influence by earning credibility and repeat invitations.

quotes.topic_title: Taking risks: the Guinness pricing pitch
quotes.text: one of the common behaviors or traits is relentless curiosity, this insatiable desire to understand things and a lack of fear in admitting when they don't understand things and being uncompromising and getting the answers so that they do understand.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A hiring/operating model for PM impact: curiosity + intellectual humility + persistence in closing knowledge gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great growth PMs
quotes.text: one of the common behaviors or traits is relentless curiosity, this insatiable desire to understand things and a lack of fear in admitting when they don't understand things and being uncompromising and getting the answers so that they do understand.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Defines a concrete, hireable behavior (curiosity + intellectual humility + persistence) that drives outsized PM impact.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great growth PMs
quotes.text: I think there's a stat that some growth person put out there years ago, which is that on average only 20 to 30% of experiments of growth team runs might be successful. So, that means 70 to 80% of the time you're, you're not putting numbers on the board and you're extracting learnings hopefully that you can apply to the future.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations for growth work and reframes “failure” as the default operating mode with learning as the output.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great growth PMs
quotes.text: If your sort of primary modality of product-led growth work is experiment-driven product development and you're hitting more than like 30, 40% of the time, you're thinking too small.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Counterintuitive benchmark: high win-rates can signal under-ambitious bets rather than strong execution.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great growth PMs
quotes.text: Valuing simple solutions to really hard problems, I think if building the next super sophisticated widget is the thing that gets you out of bed in the morning, growth might not be for you,
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Practical guidance on fit for growth PM roles: prioritize outcome-driven simplicity over complex feature-building.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great growth PMs
quotes.text: they're almost ambivalent to the solution and certainly ambivalent to how complex a solution may or may not be. And taking little to no pleasure or pride in the complexity of a solution so long that it delivers the outcome that the business and your customers need,
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for growth leadership: detach ego from solution complexity and optimize for outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: My advice to folks who are interested in breaking into product management specifically is focus on a few things. One, focus on structure.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Emphasizes choosing an environment with strong training and proven leaders over simply finding any PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: I do believe that taking a truly academic approach towards upskilling has fairly diminishing returns because it's tough to field curveballs in a classroom.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian take that challenges the idea that courses alone can prepare you for real PM work.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: And so, choosing where you want to break in is almost as important as choosing that you want to break in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: the entry context (manager, company track record) can matter as much as the career choice itself.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: go reach out to a PM and ask how you can make their day easier.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for breaking in: create value for PMs first to build trust and access.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: Figure out what you can do in your spare time that they can offload to you and do a little bit of volunteer labor, even if that's just shadowing
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Practical methodology for gaining hands-on exposure and earning sponsorship without formal PM experience.

quotes.topic_title: Learning PM craft: customers, data, and rigor
quotes.text: Literally, sometimes going outside and just talking to runners in passing to understand what were the challenges in finding motivation, and why do they choose running assistance, running applications in the first place?
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A concrete, scrappy user-research tactic PMs can apply immediately to get closer to real user needs.

quotes.topic_title: Learning PM craft: customers, data, and rigor
quotes.text: And so, having data at scale to drive decisions, being able to know that if we make a change, we can prove causation from a business impact standpoint or a customer delight or engagement standpoint.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A methodology shift from intuition to measurable experimentation, emphasizing causation and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Learning PM craft: customers, data, and rigor
quotes.text: And having a level of rigor around that and really being forced to articulate a hypothesis and have a point of view on what the outcomes might be before you actually build something, were all sort of, I would say, behaviors and just philosophy around product discipline that I learned from Fareed and that group of folks that I worked with closely during those years.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A repeatable product-discipline loop: state a hypothesis, predict outcomes, then build and validate.

quotes.topic_title: Learning PM craft: customers, data, and rigor
quotes.text: Talk to customers, and we also learned a lot from talking to people who we wanted to be customers but were not, right? And people who had either broken up with our product or evaluated it and never fell in love with it in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Expands customer discovery beyond current users to churned and never-converted prospects for sharper insights.

quotes.topic_title: Learning PM craft: customers, data, and rigor
quotes.text: You could have all the usage data in the world, that's going to tell you what's actually happening in your product, but it doesn't tell you why.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that quantitative analytics must be paired with qualitative research to uncover motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Mentors vs sponsors and seeking hard feedback
quotes.text: And I would actually describe those folks as being sponsors and advocates, people who were willing to put up capital, whether that's professional, social capital to bet on you.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A crisp framework distinguishing mentors from sponsors/advocates by whether they spend real political/social/professional capital on your behalf.

quotes.topic_title: Mentors vs sponsors and seeking hard feedback
quotes.text: When I think about true gasoline on the career fire, it's finding mentors, but it's also finding sponsors and advocates.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for career acceleration that emphasizes sponsorship alongside mentorship.

quotes.topic_title: Mentors vs sponsors and seeking hard feedback
quotes.text: Something I think I certainly continue to work on, but really, putting ego aside and embracing not knowing stuff and embracing not being good at stuff, and not feeling self-conscious about that and letting the desire to be the best at something or at least be great at something overpower the fear of being inadequate at something.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to become more coachable and attractive to mentors/sponsors by prioritizing learning over ego-protection.

quotes.topic_title: Mentors vs sponsors and seeking hard feedback
quotes.text: I can take hard feedback, and I like it because if I get better feedback than the people I'm competing against, I think I can beat them over time if I work hard enough.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian competitive advantage framing: seeking tougher feedback than peers compounds into long-term outperformance.

quotes.topic_title: Mentors vs sponsors and seeking hard feedback
quotes.text: at least what's within my control is how I can show up in the context of those relationships and really embrace even the hardest, ugliest feedback and hope that I can extract something from it that'll make me better at the end of the day.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A practical relationship-building approach: focus on controllables and treat even harsh feedback as raw material for improvement.

quotes.topic_title: What makes HubSpot special: customers and market focus
quotes.text: My point of view here is that oftentimes it's a function of what's the time horizon that the company uses as their sort of baseline for assessing decisions?
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A practical decision-making lens: many “customer vs. business” tradeoffs are really about choosing the right evaluation time horizon.

quotes.topic_title: What makes HubSpot special: customers and market focus
quotes.text: And typically, when you're making decisions that could be described as hostile towards your customers, but a net positive for the business, you're probably not thinking long-term enough, right?
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that short-term revenue wins that hurt customers are usually a sign of insufficient long-term thinking.

quotes.topic_title: What makes HubSpot special: customers and market focus
quotes.text: So, for example, you look at a lot of standard documentation for features or experiments, whatever, and one of the first things, it's like outline the problem. I don't know that we even talk about problems without a qualifier. Are we talking about a business problem? Are we talking about a customer problem? Are we talking about an efficiency problem? Describe the nature of the problem and parse it out.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: An actionable documentation practice: force specificity about the problem type to prevent solving the wrong thing.

quotes.topic_title: What makes HubSpot special: customers and market focus
quotes.text: Being a company that has been comfortable staying in the mid-market, SMB mid-market space, and resisting the temptation to try to crawl up into enterprise software, I think makes us special.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A strategic positioning insight: staying focused on SMB/mid-market can be a deliberate advantage, not a stepping stone.

quotes.topic_title: What makes HubSpot special: customers and market focus
quotes.text: And so, by playing in the mid-market, it means our revenue is distributed more evenly across our entire install base, which means that there's no single customer who can hold us hostage, really.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why customer concentration in enterprise can distort product decisions—and how a broader base changes incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Culture code and evolving rituals
quotes.text: I think it also helps in attracting the right type of candidates because we put it out there, we're sort of really open about it. If you don't like that culture, chances are you probably won't be super excited to work here.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Highlights how publishing culture externally acts as a self-selection filter to improve hiring fit.

quotes.topic_title: Culture code and evolving rituals
quotes.text: But by being really open and transparent about the culture both internally and externally, I think one, it internally creates alignment and it gives everyone something to point to to enforce why did we choose to work with each other the way that we work with each other.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Shows culture documentation as an operational tool for alignment and decision enforcement, not just branding.

quotes.topic_title: Culture code and evolving rituals
quotes.text: And being willing to sort of pressure test it on a regular basis, like is this still a company we want to be? We are growing really fast. What has changed? What conditions are still able to be supported with the culture we have codified today? What amendments might we need to make in terms of who we want to represent ourselves to be to our customers and how do we want to work with each other?
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: Provides a repeatable set of questions for evolving culture as the company scales and conditions change.

quotes.topic_title: Culture code and evolving rituals
quotes.text: "Solve for the customer, not just their happiness, but also their success."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable principle that reframes customer focus from satisfaction to measurable outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Merge's Unified API can fully remove this blocker from your roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Christopher Miller
quotes.context: Frames integrations as a roadmap blocker that can be eliminated by standardizing on a unified API approach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one API, your team can add over 180 HR, accounting, ATS, ticketing, CRM, file storage and marketing automation integrations into your product.
quotes.speaker: Christopher Miller
quotes.context: Provides a concrete scale example of how a single abstraction can unlock broad integration coverage quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can get your first integration into production in a matter of days, and save countless weeks building custom integrations, letting you get back to building your core product.
quotes.speaker: Christopher Miller
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: reduce integration toil to reallocate engineering time to core product differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Save your engineers countless hours, hit your growth targets and expedite your sales cycle by making integration offerings your competitive advantage with Merge.
quotes.speaker: Christopher Miller
quotes.context: Connects integrations to business outcomes (growth and sales velocity) and positions them as a strategic advantage rather than a cost center.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to HubSpot growth history and PLG roots
quotes.text: I think there's definitely a very legitimate school of thought around how culture can both contribute to inclusion, but also, be a headwind to inclusion.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that “strong culture” can unintentionally exclude, so teams should evaluate cultural practices through an inclusion lens.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to HubSpot growth history and PLG roots
quotes.text: I think we have to ask ourselves, "What's the value of continuing to embrace these things?"
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A practical decision filter for legacy rituals/jokes: keep only what still creates value for today’s team.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to HubSpot growth history and PLG roots
quotes.text: I think what we've been doing over the years is taking inventory of the things that might have been considered part of HubSpot legacy culture and really trying to again, pressure test it. Does this continue to serve us today? And if not, we should be really comfortable of letting it go.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: An actionable methodology for evolving culture: inventory, pressure-test for current usefulness, and intentionally retire what no longer serves.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to HubSpot growth history and PLG roots
quotes.text: There's not a ton of focus on just classic productivity. There's a ton of focus on building connections and safety and just getting to know people and who they are as human beings, but also, damn I forgot how much I missed whiteboarding.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A concrete example of designing in-person time around trust and collaboration (not just output), while leveraging high-bandwidth activities like whiteboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to HubSpot growth history and PLG roots
quotes.text: I would say the early years of doing freemium.
quotes.speaker: Chris Miller
quotes.context: A succinct pointer to a key growth lever practitioners can study and replicate: freemium as an early engine for scale.
